column1: wherewith I brought in moccum moccabitur
And yet thou being a long-snouted cur
Coulde no whit smell that all my meaning was
To give mock for mock as now is come to pass
which now thus passed if thy wit be handsome
May defend thee from mocks in time to come
By clapping fast to thy snout every day
Moccum moccabitur for a nosegay
wherewith she start up and shut her window to

which done I had no more to say nor do [...]. which now thus passed if thy wyt be handsome

wherwith she start vp and shyt her wyndowe to

column1: Or close the wall up with our English dead!
In peace there's nothing so becomes a man
As modest stillness and humility
But when the blast of war blows in our ears
Then imitate the action of the tiger:
Stiffen the sinews
Disguise fair nature with <span class=""quote"">hard-favored rage
Then lend the eye a terrible aspect
Let it pry through the portage of the head
Like the brass cannon
As fearfully as doth a gallèd rock
O'erhang and jutty his confounded base
Swilled with the wild and wasteful ocean.
Now set the teeth
Hold hard the breath
To his full height.";"* This passage represents several elements of the ""Tiger Cluster""

Savoring more of court than City
A little proud but full of pity
Light and humorous in her toying
Oft building hopes and soon destroying

Not too easy not nor too hard.
[...]
All extremes I would have bard
She should be allowed her passions
So they were but use as fashions
Sometime forward and frowning
Sometime sickly and then sowning
Every fit with change still crowning
Purly jealous I would have her
Only constant when I crave her
Tis a virtue should not save her
Thus nor her delicates should claw me
Nor her peevishness annoy me [...].";"";"";"@001296_A01_D02 Poetaster

column1: Yet when I saw it last
As black as Vulcan in the smoke of war.
A baubling vessel was he captain of
For shallow draught and bulk unprizable
With which such scatheful grapple did he make
With the most noble bottom of our fleet
That very envy and the tongue of loss
Cried fame and honour on him. - What’s the matter?
[First Officer:] Orsino
That took the Phoenix and her fraught from Candy
And this is he that did the Tiger board
When your young nephew Titus lost his leg.";"* This passage represents several elements of the ""Tiger Cluster""

column1: Beauty and youth once gone w'are like Beehives
That hath no honey
Let men prate on they do not feel our woes
For their condition differs much from ours
The older that they grow
If they lose beauty
But when our beauty fades that oftentimes
Conquers their greatest witts
There cannot be a wilder thing to see
Than an old woman.Therefore ere thou age attain
Know me thy self
column2: and use it as thou shouldst.

column1: [Crispinus:] <span class=""quote"">Under control of my dread Sovereign
We are thy Judges; thou that didst Arraign
Art now prepared for condemnation;
Should I but bid thy Muse stand to the Bar
Thyself against her wouldst give evidence:
For flat rebellion 'gainst the Sacred laws
Of divine Poesy: herein most she mist
Thy pride and scorn made her turn Satirist
And not her love to virtue (as thou Preachest)
Or should we minister strong pills to thee:
What lumps of hard and indigested stuff
Of bitter Satirism
Of Self-love
And stinging Insolence should we fetch up?
But none of these
column2: we give thee what's more fit

Bright as Eoan fire.

For I to thee and thine immortal name

column1: By famine
The hectic fever
Should never hurt me; nor the tardy gout:
But in my time
<span class=""quote"">By a strong tedious talker
And almost bring me to consumption.
Therefore (if I were wise) she warned me shun
All such long-winded monsters
For if I could but scape that one discourser
I might (no doubt) prove an old aged man.

you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was;"unedited";"_ Anonymous";"British Library Additional MS 15227";"89 [normalized spelling].";"1601";"1607";"";"";"English";"Do but look on her eyes they do light
All that love's world compriseth
Do but look on her hair it is bright
As Love's star when it riseth
Do but mark
Than words that sooth her
And from her arched brows such a grace
Sheds itself through the face;
As there alone triumphs to the Life
All the gain
Have you seen but a white Lily grow
Before rude hands have touched it?
Or have you marked the fall of the Snow
Before the soil hath smutched it?
Have you felt of the beaver?
Or Swansdown
Or have smelt of the bud in the briar?
Or the nard in the Fire?
Or
column2: have tasted the bag of the bee?

Than Vico Mercatus or Scaliger natus
Than Nintius or Zabarella.
Hurtado strombitus
Zanarious and Will de Hales
With Occham Javellus
Philoponus
The Conciliator was a mere prater
And so was Apollinares
Jandunus
With Masius Flavel and Suarez
Farseca
Pererius
Old Trimegistus whose volumes have missed us
Ammonius
Mirandula comes with Proilus and Somes
And Guido the Carmelita.
The Nominal Schools and the College of fools
No longer are my delight-a.
Hang Brerewood
Leave Keckerman to bemoan us.
I'll be no more beaten for greasy Jack Seton
Nor conning of Sandersonus
The Censures of Catoes shall never amaze us
Their frosty beards cannot nip us!
Your ale is too muddy

you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was;"unedited";"_ Anonymous";"British Library Additional MS 15227";"Anon. Manuscript miscellany. British Library Additional MS 15227. 75 verso [normalized spelling].";"1601";"1607";"";"";"English";"Hence all ye fond delights
As short as are the nights
Where mad men spend their folly
There's nought in this world sweet
If men were wise to see't
save only melancholy.
Welcome folded arms and fixed eyes.
A sight that piercing mortifies
A looke that’s fastened on the ground
A tongue chained up without a sound
A moonlight walk when all the fowls
Are safely housed but Bats and Owls.
A midnight bell a parting groan

These are the sounds we feed upon.";"";"";"@005393 British Library Additional MS 15227";"";"WoPa#004363 Hence all you vain delights";"Work unmarked";"Author unmarked";"Manuscript miscellany";"";"";"ANTHOLOGY ENTRY";"MQ_GENRE";"Scholarly database";"@006121-Last accessed 4 October 2019.";"Hence all ye fond delights
As short as are ye nights
Where mad men spend their folly
There's nought in this world sweet
If men were wise to see't
save only melancholy.
Welcome folded armes and fixed eyes.
A sight that piercing mortifies
A looke that’s fastned on ye ground
A tongue chain'd up without a sound
A monelight walke when all ye fouls
Are safely hous'd but Batts and Owles.
A midnight bell a parting groane
These are ye sounds wee feed upon.";"Anon. Manuscript miscellany. British Library Additional MS 15227. 75 verso.";" Hohl Regula"

column4: lines 163- 173";"1604";"1604";"1604";"1604";"English";"[Iago:] <span class=""quote"">She that was ever fair and never proud

column1: Had tongue at will and yet was never loud
Never lacked gold and yet went never gay
Fled from her wish
She that being angered
Bade her wrong stay and her displeasure fly
She that in wisdom never was so frail
To change the cod's head for the salmon's tail
She that could think and ne'er disclose her mind
See suitors following and not look behind
She was a wight

column1: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was;"unedited";"William Shakespeare";"King Lear";"Shakespeare
You are not worth the dust which the rude wind
Blows in your face. I fear your disposition.
That nature which contemns its origin
Cannot be bordered certain in itself.
She that herself will sliver and disbranch
From her material sap perforce must wither
And come to deadly use. [...]
Tigers
A father
Whose reverence even the head-lugged bear would lick
Most barbarous
[Goneril:] Milk-livered man
That bear'st a cheek for blows
column2: a head for wrongs [...].";"* This passage represents several elements of the ""Tiger Cluster""

column1: <span class=""quote"">Come my Caelia let us prove
While we can
Time will not be ours for ever;
He
Spend not then his gifts in vain.
Suns that set may rise again.
But if once we lose this light
'Tis with us perpetual night
Why should we defer our joys
Fame and rumour are but toys.
Cannote we delude the eyes
Of a few poor household spies?
Or his easier ears beguile
Thus removèd by our wile?
'Tis no sin love's fruits to steal
But the sweet thefts to reveal.
To be taken

These have crimes accounted been.";"";"";"@001493_A06_D07 Volpone";"Joseph Taylor";"WoPa#004234 Sweet Caelia let us prove";"Work unmarked";"Author unmarked";"Comedy";"";"Dialogue";"BODY OF TEXT";"";"Scholarly database";"@006121-Last accessed 25 October 2019.";"SONG.
Come my Caelia let us proue
While we can the sports of loue
Time will not be ours for ever
He at length our good will seuer
spend not then his giftes in vaine.
Sunnes
But if
'Tis with us perpetuall night
Why should we deferre our ioyes
Fame
Cannote we delude the eyes
Of a few poor houshold spies?
Or his easier eares beguile
Thus remooued by our wile?
It's no sinne
But the sweet thefts to reueale.
To be taken
These haue crimes accounted beene.";"Jonson

column1: Mortal to cut it off; to cure it easy.

column1: Were to us all that do 't and suffer it

column1: All that love's world compriseth
Do but look on her hair it is bright
As Loves star when it rises
Do but mark
Than words that soothe her
And from her arched brows such a grace
Sheds itself through the face;
As alone there triumphs to the Life
All the gain
Have you seen but a bright lily grow
Before rude hands have touched it?
have you marked but the fall of the Snow
Before the soil hath smutched it?
Have you felt wool o' the beaver?
Or swan's down
Or have smelt o' the bud o' the briar d?
Or the nard i'the Fire?
Or
column2: have tasted the bag o'the bee?

column1: And bad him into the Peak to dinner
Where never the friend had such a feast
Provided him yet at the charge of a sinner.
His stomach was queasy (he came thither coached)
The jogging had made some Crudities rise
To help it he called for a Puritanpoached
That used to turn up the eggs of his eyes.
And so recovered to his wish
He sat him down and he fell to eat
Promoter in plum broth was his first dish
His own privy kitchen had no such meat.
Yet (though with this he much were taken)
Upon a sudden he shifted his trencher
As soon as he spied the Bawd and Bacon
By which you may note the Devil's a wencher
Six pickled tailors sliced and cut
Sempsters tirewomen fit for his palate
With feathermen and perfumers put
Some twelve in a charger to make a grand salad.
A rich fat usurer in his marrow
And by him on lawyer's head and green sauce
Both which his belly took in like a barrow
As if till then he never had seen sauce.
Then carbonadoed and cooked with pains
Was brought up a cloven sergeant's face
The sauce was made of a yeomans brains
that had been beaten out with his own mace.
Two roasted Sheriffs came whole to the board
The feast had nothing been without 'em
Both living and dead they were foxed and furred
Their chains like sausages hung about 'em.
The next dish was the mayor of a town
With a pudding of maintenance thrust in his belly
Like a goose in his feathers dressed in his gown
And his couple of hench-boys boiled to a jelly
A London cuckold hot from the spit
And when the carver up had broke him
The devil chopped up his head at a bit
But the horns were very near to choke him
Yet though with the meat he was much taken
up on a sudden he shifted his trencher
as soon as he spied the bawd and bacon
by which you may know the devil is a wencher
The chin of a lecher too there was roasted
With a plump young harlot's haunch and garlic
A pander's pettitoes that had boasted
Himself for a captain yet never was warlike
A lusty fat pasty of a midwife hot
And for a cold baked meat into the story
A reverend painted lady was brought
Was coffined in crust till she was hoary
To these an overgrown justice of peace
With a clerk like a gizzard trussed under each arm
And warrant for sippets laid in his own grease
Set over a chafing-dish to be kept warm
The jowl of a jailor served for fish
A constable soused with vinegar by
Two aldermen lobsters asleep in a dish
A deputy tart and a churchwarden pie
All which devoured he then for a close
Did for a full draught of Derby call
He heaved the huge vessel up to his nose
And left not till he had drunk up all.
Then from the table he gave a start
Where banquet and wine was nothing scarce
All which he blew away with a fart

From whence it was called the Devil's Arse.";"";"#009027 Marquess of Buckingham's household / #008027 RUTLAND_Burley-on-the-Hill";"@001987_A21_D40 The Gypsies Metamorphosed";"";"WoPa#004352 Cook Lawrick invited the devil / NaHu_NewWot#007019 Jonson

column1: As short as are the nights
Wherein you spend your folly.
There 's naught in this life sweet
If men were wise to see't
But only melancholy
O sweetest melancholy.
Welcome folded arms and fixéd eyes
A sight that piercing mortifies
A look that's fastened to the ground
A tongue chained up without a sound
Fountain-heads and pathless groves
(Places which pale passion loves)
Moonlight walks
Are warmly housed
A midnight bell
These are the sounds we feed upon
Then stretch our bones in a still gloomy valley:

Nothing's so dainty sweet as lovely melancholy.";"";"";"@002023_A22_D47 The Nice Valour";"";"WoPa#004230 hence you fond delights";"Work unmarked";"Author unmarked";"Theatre";"";"Dialogue";"BODY OF TEXT";"";"Scholarly database";"@006121-Last accessed 23 October 2019.";"[Passionate Lord (sings):] Hence all you vaine Delights
As short as are the nights
Wherein you spend your folly.
There 's naught in this life sweet
If men were wise to see't
But onely Melancholy
O sweetest melancholy.
Welcome folded Armes and fixéd eyes
A sight that piercing mortifies
A look that's fastned to the ground
A tongue chain'd up without a sound
Fountaine heads and pathlesse Groves
(Places which pale passion loves)
Moon-light walkes
Are warmly hous'd
A mid-night Bell
These are the sounds we feed upon
Then stretch our bones in a still gloomy valley:
Nothing's so daintie sweet as lovely melancholy.";"Middleton

column1: Then Faber Parisiensis
Then Scotus Socinus
Or Gregory Gandavensis
Than Cardan and Ramus
Albertus or Gabriella
Than Pico mercatus or Scaliger natus
Than Nyphus or Zabarella.
Hortado Tromberus
Zanardus and Will de Hales
With Occam Javellus
Philoponus
The Conciliator was but a mere prater
And so was Apollinaris
Tandunus
With Masius and Suarez
Fonseca
Pererius
Old Trismegistus (whose volumes have missed us)
Ammonius
Mirandula comes with Proclus and Somes
And Guido the Carmelit-a.
The nominal schools and the college of fools
No longer is my delight-a.
Hang Brerewood
Let Keckerman too bemoan us. continued
I'll be no more beaten for greasy Jack Seaton
Or conning of Sandersonus
The censure of Catos shall never amate us
Their frosty beards cannot nip us!
Your ale is too muddy
Our tutor Aristippus. ";"";"#008012 CAMBRIDGE_Trinity College

column1: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was;"unedited";"_ Anonymous";"Bodleian Library MS English Poetry e 14";"Anon.  Manuscript miscellany. Bodleian Library MS English poetry e. 14.  12 [normalized spelling].";"1630";"1639";"";"";"English";"16 <span class=""quote"">Still to be neat
As if you were going to a feast
Stil to be powdered
Lady it is to be presumed
Where art's hid causes are not found
All is not Sweet
Give me a look give me a face
That make simplicity a grace
Robes loosely hanging hair as free
Such sweet neglects best pleases me
There all the adulteries of art

May please my eye but not my heart [...].";"** This manuscript commonplace book contains four extracts from plays by Ben Jonson and one from Francius Beaumont's Nice Valour";"";"@005386 Bodleian Library MS English Poetry e 14";"";"WoPa#004290 still to be neat";"Work unmarked";"Author unmarked";"Manuscript miscellany";"";"";"ANTHOLOGY ENTRY";"MQ_GENRE";"Scholarly database";"@006121-Last accessed 22 October 2019.";"16 Stil to be neat
As if you were going to a feast
Stil to be pawdred
Lady it is to be presumd
Wher arts hid causes are not found
Al is not Sweet
Give me a looke give me a face
That make simplicity a grace
Robs loosly hanging hair as free
Such swet neclets best pleases me
There all the adulterys of art
May please my eye but not my hart [...].";"Anon. Manuscript miscellany. Bodleian Library MS English poetry e. 14. 12.";" Hohl Regula"
you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was;"unedited";"_ Anonymous";"Bodleian Library MS English Poetry e 14";"21 recto [normalized spelling].";"1630";"1639";"";"";"English";"The choice of lover
If I freely may discover
What may please me in my lover
I would have her fair and witty
Savouring more of court than City
A little proud but full of pity
Light and humorous in her toying
Oft building hopes and soon destroying
Not too easy nor too hard
All extremes I would have barred
She should be allowed her passions
So they were but used as fashions
Sometime froward and frowning
Sometime sickly and then sowning
Every fit with change still crowning
Purly jealous I would have her
Only constant when I crave her
'Tis a virtue should not save her
Thus nor her delicates should cloy me

Nor her peevishness annoy me [...].";"";"";"@005386 Bodleian Library MS English Poetry e 14";"";"WoPa#004291 freely may discover";"Work unmarked";"Author unmarked";"Manuscript miscellany";"";"";"ANTHOLOGY ENTRY";"MQ_GENRE / MQ_TYPOGRAPHY_Heading";"Scholarly database";"@006121-Last accessed 23 October 2019.";"The choyce of lover
If I frely may discover
What may please me in my lover
I would have her faire and witty
Savouring more of court then Citty
A little proud but full of pitty
Light and humorous in her toying
Oft building hopes and soone destroying
Not too easy notnor too hard
All extreams I would have bard
She should be allowd her passions
Soe they were but usd as fashions
Sometime froward and frowning
Sometime sickly and then sowning
Every fitt with chang still crowning
Purly ieas iealous I would have her
Only constant when I crave her
Tis a virtue should not save her
Thus nor her delicats should cloy mee
Nor her peevishnese anoy mee [...].";"21 recto.";" Hohl Regula"

you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was;"unedited";"_ Anonymous";"Bodleian Library MS English Poetry e 14";"84 verso [normalized spelling].";"1630";"1639";"";"";"English";"The Image of Melancholy
225 Hence all you fond delight
As short as are ye nights
Wherein your spend your folly
There's nothing truly sweet
If men could truly see't
Save only melancholy
Come folded arms and fixed eyes
A sight that piercing mortifies
A look that's fastened to the ground
A tong chained without a sound
Fountainheads and pathless groves
Places where pale passion loves
Moonlight walks
Are warmly housed save bats and owls
A midnight's groanbell a parting groan
These are the sounds wee feed upon
Then stretch your limbs in a still gloomy valley

There's naught in the life sweet save melancholy [...].";"";"";"@005386 Bodleian Library MS English Poetry e 14";"";"WoPa#004230 hence you fond delights";"Work unmarked";"Author unmarked";"Manuscript miscellany";"";"";"ANTHOLOGY ENTRY";"MQ_GENRE / MQ_TYPOGRAPHY_Heading";"Scholarly database";"@006121-Last accessed 22 October 2019.";" The Image of Melancolly
225 Hence all you fond delight
As short as are ye nights
Wherein your spend yr folly
Ther 's nothing truly sweet
If men could truly see't
Save only malancolly
Come foulded armes and fixed eyes
A sight yt pearcing mortifys
A looke yts fastned to ye ground
A toung chan'd without a sound
Fountaine heads and pathlese growes
Places wher pale passion loves
Moonli ght walkes
Are warmly housd save bats & owls
A midnight's groanebell a parting groane
These are ye sounds wee feed upon
Then streach your limbs in a still gloomy vally
Thers naught in ye life sweet save melancoly [...].";"84 verso.";" Hohl Regula"

column1: <span class=""quote"">Still to be neat
As you were going to a feast;
Still to be powdered
Lady it is to be presumed
Though art's hid causes are not found
All is not sweet
Give me a look
That makes simplicity a grace:
Robe loosely hanging
Such sweet neglect more taketh me.
Then all the spurious feats of art
They please mine eyes
column2: but not my heart.";"";"";"@005360 British Library Additional MS 10309";"";"NaHu_NewWot#007019 Jonson

column1: <span class=""quote"">Still to be neat
As you were goeing to a feast;
Still to be pouder'd
Ladie it is to be presum'd
Though arts hid causes are not found
All is not sweete
Give me a looke
That makes simplicitie a grace:
Roabe loosely hanging
Such sweet neglect more taketh me.
Then all the spurious feats of art
They please mine eyes

column1: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was;"unedited";"Margaret Bellasys";"British Library Additional MS 10309";"117 recto [normalized spelling].";"1630";"1630";"1630";"1630";"English";"By Ben Jonson
Come Sweet Caelia let us prove
While we may the sports of Love
Time will not be ours for ever
He at length our bliss will sever
Spend not then his gifts in vain
Suns that set
But if we once lose this light
It's with us perpetual night
Why should we defer our joys
Fame
Cannote we delude the eyes?
Of a few poor household spies.
And his easier ears beguile
Soe removed by many a mile.
It's no sin love's fruits to steal
But the sweet thefts to reveal.
To be taken
These hath crimes accounted been.";"";"";"@005360 British Library Additional MS 10309";"";"NaHu_NewWot#007019 Jonson
column2: Ben / WoPa#004234 Sweet Caelia let us prove";"Work unmarked";"Author name";"Manuscript miscellany";"";"";"ANTHOLOGY ENTRY";"MQ_GENRE / MQ_TYPOGRAPHY_Heading";"Scholarly database / morethanonelexia";"@006121-Last accessed 25 October 2019.";"By Ben Jonson

column1: Come Sweet Caelia let us prove
While we may ye sports of Love
Time will not be ors for ever
He at length or blisse will sever
Spen not then his giftes in vaine
Suns that set
But if we once loose this light
It's wth us perpetuall night
Why should we defer or joys
Fame
Cannote we delude the eyes?
Of a few poore household spyes.
And his easier eares beguile
Soe remov'd by many a mile.
It's no sinne loves fruits to steale
But the sweet thefts to reveale.
To be taken
These hath crimes accounted beene.";"117 recto.";" Hohl Regula"

you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was;"unedited";"_ Anonymous";"Bodleian Library MS English Poetry e 14";"12 [normalized spelling].";"1630";"1639";"";"";"English";"Ben Johnson on the Peake
1 Cook Lawrick invited the devil his guest
and bid once in the Peak to dinner
where never friend had such a feast
provided yet at the cost of a sinner
2 His stomach was queasy he came thither coached
the jogging caused some crudities to rise
to help him he called for a puritan poached
that used to turne up the eggs off his eyes
3 And so recovered himself to his wish
he sat him down to his drink and to eat
promoter in plum broth was his first dish
his own private chicken had no such meat
4 Six pickled tailors shred and cut
Seamster's fair women fit for his pallet
with feathermen and perfumers all put
some 12 in charger to make a grand salad
5 A rich fat usurer in his marrow
by him on lawer and greene sauce
which use to eat 2 legs of a scarrow
and then go and his money case
6 There carbonaded and cooked with pains
was brought up a cloven sergeant's face
the sauce was made of a yeoman's brains
that had been cloven out with his own mace
7 Two wasted sheriffs came next to the board
the feast had nothing been without them
both living and dead they were foxed and furred
their chains like sausages hung about them
8 The next dish was the mayor of their town
with a pudding of maintenance put in his belly
like a goose in his feathers dressed in his old gown
and couple of hench boys boiled for jelly
9 A London cuckold hot from the spit
and when the carver him broken
the devil chops up his head at a bit
but the horns were very nigh to have choked him
10 Yet though with the meat he was much taken
up on a sudden he shifted his trencher
as soon as he spied the bawd and bacon
by which you may know the devil is a wencher
11 The chin of a lecher too there was roasted
with a plumpe young whore's haunch and garlic
a pander patatoes that had boasted
himself for a captaine yet never was warlike
12 A lusty fat pasty of a midwife hot
and for a cold bake dish in the story
a reverend painted lady was brought
was coffined in crust till she was hoary
13 To those a overgrown justice of peace
with a clerk like gizzard thrust under each arm
with a warnent for syppits laid in his owne grease
set over a chafing-dish to be kept warm
14 The jowl of a jailor served for fish
a constable soused vith vinegar by
two aldermen lobsters asleep in a dish
a deputy tart and a churchwarden pie
15 All which devoured he then for a close
Did for a full draught of Derby ale call
and heaves the huge vessel into his nose
and ceased not till he had drunk up all
16 Then from the table he gan to start
When banquet and wine was nothing short
all which he blew away with a fart

from whence it was called the devil arse.";"";"";"@005386 Bodleian Library MS English Poetry e 14";"";"WoPa#004352 Cook Lawrick invited the devil";"Work unmarked";"Author unmarked";"Manuscript miscellany";"";"";"ANTHOLOGY ENTRY";"MQ_GENRE / MQ_TYPOGRAPHY_Heading";"Scholarly database";"@006121-Last accessed 3 October 2019.";"Ben Johnson on the Peake
1 Cook Lawrick invited the divell his guest
and bid once in the Peake to dinner
where never freind had such a feast
provided yet at the cost of a sinner
2 His stomacke was queasy he came thither coacht
the jogging causd some cruditys to rise
to help him hee cald for a puritan poacht
that use to turne up the eggs off his eyes
3 And soe recover'd himself to his wish
he sat him downe to his drincke and to eat
promoter in plumbroth was his first dish
his owne privet chicken had no such meat
4 Six picled tailors shred and cut
Seamsters faire women fit for his pallet
with feathermen and perfumers all put
some 12 in charger to make a grand sallet
5 A rich fat userer in his marrow
by him on lawer and greene sawce
which use to eat 2 legs of a scarrow
and then goe and his mony case
6 Ther carbonaded and cookt with paines
was brought up a cloven sergaints face
the sawce was made of a yeomans braines
that had been cloven out with his owne mace
7 Two wasted sherrifes came next to the board
the feast had nothing been without them
both living and dead they were foxt and furd
ther chaines like sawsages hung about them
8 The next dish was the maior of ther towne
with a puddin of maintenance put in his belly
like a gouse in his feathers drest in his old gowne
and cupple of hinch boys boyld for ielly BM at the moment the fact that this extract runs over two folios is not showing up on DEx [same song cont'd; bottom of page non-dramatic]
9 A London cookold hot from the spit
and when the carver him broken
the divill chops up his head at a bit
but the hornes were very nigh to have chockt him
10 Yet though with the meat he was much taken
up on a sudden hee sheifted his treancher
as soon as he spyd the baud and bacon
by by which you may know the divill is a wencher
11 The chine of a leacher to ther was roasted
with a plumpe youg whore's hanch and garlicke
a pander patitoes that had boasted
himself for a captaine yt never was warlike
12 A lusty fat pasty of a midwife hot
and for a colde bake dish in the story
a reverent painted lady was brought
was coffind in crust till she was hory
13 To those a overgrowne justice of peace
with a clarke like gyzard thrust under each arme
with a warnent for syppits laid in his owne grease
set over a chafingdish to be kept warme
14 The jowle of a iailor served for fish
a counstable soust vist vinegar by
two alder men lobsters a sleepe in a dish
a debuty tart and a churchwarden pye
15 All which devoured he then for a close
Did for a full draught of darby aall call
and heaves the huge vessel in to his nose
and ceast not till hee had druncke up all
16 Then from the table he gan to start
When banquit and wine was nothing sc
all which hee blew away with a fart
from whence it was cald the divill arse";"12.";" Hohl Regula"
you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was;"unedited";"_ Anonymous";"Bodleian Library MS English Poetry e 14";"20 recto [normalized spelling].";"1630";"1639";"";"";"English";"Of love
Love is sickness full of woe
All remedy refusing
A plant that most by cutting grow
Most barren with best using
Why so?
More we enioy more it dies
If not enjoyed sighing cries
Hey ho?
Love is a torment of the mind
A tempest everlasting
And Jove hath made of a kind
Not well
Why so?
More we enjoy it more it dies
If not enjoyed
Hey

column1: They with their double key of conscience bind

column1: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was;"unedited";"William Deedes";"Folger MS V.a.226 vol. 1";"53 recto [normalized spelling].";"1660";"1687";"1660";"1687";"English";"<span class=""quote"">Poor Princes
While they whose sacred office 'tis to bring
Kings to obey their God
By those mysterious links to fix and tie
Them to the footstool of the Deity;
Even by these men
The curb
column2: is made the spur to Tyranny.

column1: They with their double key of conscience bind
The Subjects' souls
While their poor vassals sacrifice their bloods
T'Ambition
Blind with Devotion. They themselves esteem.
Made for themselves
column2: and all the world for them;

column1: While heaven's great Law
Just or unjust
column2: but as it waits on theirs:

column1: Used but to give the echo of their words
Power lo their wills; and edges to their swords.
To varnish all their errors
The ills they act
Thus by their arts Kings are the world while they
Religion
Yet as their slave command her: while they seem
To rise to Heaven
column2: they make Heaven stoop to them.";"";"";"@005385 Folger MS V a 226 vol 1";"";"WoPa#004244 Poor princes how misled";"Work unmarked";"Author unmarked";"Manuscript miscellany";"";"";"ANTHOLOGY ENTRY";"MQ_GENRE";"Scholarly database";"@006121-Last accessed 27 October 2019.";"Poor Princes

column1: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was;"unedited";"_ Anonymous";"University of Chicago MS 824";"Anon.  Manuscript miscellany. University of Chicago MS 824.  113 recto [normalized spelling].";"1674";"1684";"";"";"English";"<span class=""quote"">Give thy thoughts no tongue
nor any Unproportioned thought his Act
Be thou Familiar
those Friends thou hast and their Adoption tried
Grapple them unto thy soul with Hoops of steel:
But do not dull thy Palm with Entertainment
of each new hatched; unfledged Courages: beware
of entrance to a Quarrel
bear 't that the opposer may beware of thee;
Give every man thy ear
take each man's Censure
Neither a borrower nor a Lender Be
for Love oft loses both itself and Friend
and borrowing Dulls the edge of Husbandry

to thine owne self be true. ";"";"";"@005384 University of Chicago MS 824";"";"WoPa#030081 Polonius' advice to Laertes";"Work unmarked";"Author unmarked";"Manuscript miscellany";"";"";"ANTHOLOGY ENTRY";"MQ_GENRE / MQ_VERBAL_Generalization";"Scholarly database";"@006121-Last accessed 3 October 2019.";"Give thy thoughts noe tongue
nor any Unproportione'd thought his Act
Bee thou Familliar
those Friends thou hast & their Adoption tryed
Grapple them unto thy soule with Hoopes of steele:
But doe not dull thy Palme with Entertainment
of each new hatcht; unfledg'd Courages: beware
of entrance to a Quarrell
bear’t that the opposer may beware of thee;
Give every man thy eare
take each mans Censure
Neither a borrower nor a Lender Bee
for Love oft loses both it selfe & Friend
and borrowing Dulls the edge of Husbandry
to thine owne selfe be true. /span";"113 recto.";"   Hohl Regula"
